prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Susato Mikotoba
Description: A judicial assistant sent to Britain on a study tour. She's the epitome of a refined Japanese lady and a huge help to me always.
Character 1
Name: Iris Wilson
Description: An extraordinary young girl who lives with Mr Sholmes. She has a degree in medicine and is the author of a popular series of short stories.
Character 2
Name: Herlock Sholmes
Description: There's not a person in the world who hasn't heard of this famous great detective, whose deductions never fail to surprise.
Character 3
Name: Mael Stronghart
Description: The Lord Chief Justice, who wields absolute authority in judicial matters, including the appointment of lawyers. He's a thoroughly intimidating man.
Character 4
Name: Odie Asman
Description: The man who perished in the explosion on the experimentation stage at the Great Exhibition of London.↳The man who perished in the explosion on the experimentation stage. He was Professor Harebrayne's financial backer and the boss of a large criminal organisation.
Character 5
Name: Albert Harebrayne
Description: A scientist who invented a machine to demonstrate super-high-voltage instantaneous kinesis. However, it exploded in use, and he is now accused of murder.↳A scientist who invented a machine to demonstrate super-high-voltage instantaneous kinesis. He's the defendant of this case and a friend to Lord van Zieks, apparently.
Character 6
Name: Barok van Zieks
Description: A prosecutor known as the Reaper of the Bailey. Supposedly, the souls of those he prosecutes are eternally damned, one way or another.
Character 7
Name: Masked Man
Description: An apprentice of Lord van Zieks whose face is always covered by a mask. He has the air of a completely unassailable man.
Character 8
Name: Gina Lestrade
Description: A mostly reformed pickpocket who's now a self-appointed 'detective inspector'. She's really making waves in her new apprenticeship.
Character 9
Name: Tobias Gregson
Description: The detective inspector in charge of Scotland Yard's investigation of the case. He's stern and single-minded in his approach, and a great lover of fish and chips.
Character 10
Name: Esmeralda Tusspells
Description: The proprietress of the Madame Tusspells Museum of Waxwork and the latest in a line of artisans privy to the secret Tusspells technique of capturing a perfect likeness.
Character 11
Name: Balthazar Lune
Description: The impresario of short pleasure voyages in flying balloons. The balloons above the experimentation state all belonged to this man.
Character 12
Name: Bohemian Boy
Description: A young boy who came to London to visit the Great Exhibition. His real name is Wilhelm Gottsreich Sigismond Ormstein.↳A young prince from the royal family of Bohemia with an excessively long name. He witnessed the explosion at the Great Exhibition.
Character 13
Name: Courtney Sithe
Description: Scotland Yard coroner, leader of the Forensic Investigation Team and one of Lord Stronghart's most trusted allies.
Character 14
Name: Enoch Drebber
Description: A trickster who seems to be both an engineer and a magician. He constructed the machine for Professor Harebrayne's demonstration.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Armband
Description: An armband I inherited from Kazuma. It identifies the wearer as a defence lawyer throughout the Empire of Japan.
Evidence 1
Name: Great Exhibition Newspaper
Description: A newspaper containing various articles about the world-leading science and technology on show at the Great Exhibition being held in London.
Evidence 2
Name: Experiment Sketch
Description: A diagram showing the relative positions of the Crystal Tower and Professor Harebrayne's machine that exploded.
Evidence 3
Name: Mysterious Contraption → Crossbow
Description: A very curious device found behind a tree under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds, almost as if it had been hidden there deliberately. A weapon found hidden behind a tree under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds. It turns out that it's a folding crossbow. A crossbow found hidden behind a tree under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds. It belongs to Mr Enoch Drebber.
Evidence 4
Name: Piece of Green Cloth
Description: A torn piece of canvas-like material backed with rubber that was found under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds. There are scorch marks at the edges.
Evidence 5
Name: Photograph of the Victim
Description: A photographic print of the victim taken after he had ostensibly been 'beamed' to the Crystal Tower. It shows an apparent stab wound to the chest.
Evidence 6
Name: Autopsy Report
Description: The autopsy report of the victim, Mr Asman. His neck was broken from the impact of a violent fall and he was stabbed in the chest with a sharp object.
Evidence 7
Name: Screwdriver
Description: Professor Harebrayne's trusty screwdriver that he's named 'Andrew'. There are traces of blood at the tip and it matches the shape of the victim's wound. A metal screwdriver that was found poking through the grille in the base of what remains of the kinesis machine. It has a very distinctive handle.
Evidence 8
Name: Photograph of the Balloon
Description: A photograph taken by Gotts whilst he was riding in a balloon. It shows another balloon that he claims was green and exploded moments after he took this shot.
Evidence 9
Name: Drebber's Card
Description: Mr Enoch Drebber's business card, though it shows only the man's name. There is no address. Mr Enoch Drebber's business card, which lists no address for the man. There is a smear of machine oil on the reverse.
Evidence 10
Name: Wooden 'Birdcage'
Description: The wooden cage that was used for Professor Harebrayne's experiment. This cage, with the victim inside, crashed down into the Crystal Tower. The wooden cage that was used for the demonstration. It crashed down, with the victim inside, into the Crystal Tower causing damage to its base.
Evidence 11
Name: Photograph of Drebber
Description: A photographic print of the engineer, Mr Enoch Drebber. It's hard to make out, but he appears to be wearing a monocle with black glass.
Evidence 12
Name: Camera
Description: The camera from around the neck of a waxwork in the Madame Tusspells Special Exhibit. The actual camera that Mr Drebber had with him ten years ago when he went graverobbing. The actual camera that Mr Drebber had with him ten years ago when he went graverobbing. When the lens is extended, dark staining can be seen on the bellows.
Evidence 13
Name: Piece of Broken Glass
Description: A small fragment of very unusual and thick glass that was found in the folds of the clothing of the Professor waxwork. It would appear to be from the Crystal Tower.
Evidence 14
Name: Science Trophy
Description: A Royal Society trophy for excellence in science that was found in Mr Drebber's workshop. It's a very prestigious award for a young scientist.
Evidence 15
Name: Waxwork Head
Description: The head of the Professor waxwork that was stolen from the Madame Tusspells Special Exhibit.
Evidence 16
Name: Killer's Autopsy Report
Description: The autopsy report of the mass murderer known as the Professor, who was tried and found guilty by closed trial ten years ago.
Evidence 17
Name: Post-Explosion Photograph
Description: A photographic print of the experimentation stage after it was completely levelled by a time bomb. The metal floor of the stage has been blown open by the explosion.
Evidence 18
Name: Drebber's Contract
Description: The contract between Mr Asman and Mr Drebber detailing the terms by which they would profit from the kinesis experiment.
Evidence 19
Name: Ten-Year-Old Article
Description: A newspaper article recounting the tale of an eyewitness to the alleged 'resurrection' of the Professor from his grave on the night of his execution.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: I met the young professor approximately one year ago, through Mr Asman's introduction.
Person: Drebber
Testimony 1
Testimony: He provided me with the blueprints and I constructed the machine to his precise specifications. It was no trick.
Person: Drebber
Testimony 2
Testimony: If the whole show was a fraud, it would have required a body double. Tell me...did the victim have a twin?
Person: Drebber
Testimony 3
Testimony: All the spectators saw the birdcage appear above their heads and then crash headfirst into the Crystal Tower.
Person: Drebber
Testimony 4
Testimony: The kinesis clearly took place, because there's nowhere else thirty feet high for the birdcage to have fallen from.
Person: Drebber
Testimony 5
Testimony: A terrible accident, I grant you. Perhaps the science on which the machine was built was flawed somehow?
Person: Drebber

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, let's tackle this problem. I need to find which evidence contradicts one of the testimonies provided. Let me start by going through each testimony and cross-referencing them with the evidence.

Looking at Testimony 3 by Drebber: He says all spectators saw the birdcage appear above their heads and crash into the Crystal Tower. But looking at the evidence, Evidence 10 (Wooden 'Birdcage') states that the cage crashed into the Crystal Tower, causing damage. However, Evidence 17 (Post-Explosion Photograph) shows the experimentation stage was leveled by a time bomb, which would have destroyed the stage before the birdcage could crash into the tower. Wait, if the stage was blown up, how did the birdcage end up in the tower? That seems contradictory. So Drebber's testimony claims the birdcage was seen crashing into the tower, but the explosion from the time bomb (Evidence 17) would have destroyed the stage and possibly the setup before that could happen. Alternatively, maybe the explosion was after the crash? Hmm, need to check the timeline. The autopsy report (Evidence 6) mentions the victim died from a broken neck from a fall and a stab wound. The photograph of the victim (Evidence 5) shows a stab wound, but the screwdriver (Evidence 7) with blood matches the wound. Wait, but if the victim was in the birdcage that crashed, then the broken neck would be from the fall. However, the machine exploded (per the case description), and the time bomb (Evidence 17) would have caused the explosion. So Drebber's Testimony 3 says the birdcage crashed into the tower, implying the machine worked as intended (kinesis moved it there), but the time bomb exploding the stage (Evidence 17) might indicate that the machine's explosion happened first, making the birdcage's crash impossible. Therefore, the existence of the time bomb's explosion (Evidence 17) contradicts the testimony that the birdcage was moved by the machine's kinesis and crashed into the tower. Alternatively, maybe the time bomb was set to explode after the birdcage was launched. But according to Evidence 17, the stage was completely leveled by the explosion, which would mean the machine was destroyed. If the machine was destroyed, how did it send the birdcage up? So the testimony says the birdcage appeared above (due to the machine working), but the explosion would have destroyed the machine before that could happen. Therefore, Evidence 17 (Post-Explosion Photograph) contradicts Testimony 3.

Testimony 5

cot:
Okay, let's see. I need to find which evidence and testimony contradict each other. Let's start by looking through the testimonies and the evidence to spot inconsistencies.

The testimonies are all from Esmeralda Tusspells (Character 10). Let's go through them one by one. Testimony 0 says the special exhibit is based on a shocking rumor. Testimony 1 mentions taking an impression from the corpse according to family principles. Testimony 2 talks about enlisting a gravedigger to create a mold before interment. Testimony 3 says she hid until a signal and was there a long time. Testimony 4 mentions it took a long time because it was before rigor mortis. Testimony 5 is about being worried as dawn approached. Testimony 6 says she hurried to finish in the half hour before sunrise and left after interment.

Now looking at the evidence. Evidence 12 is the camera from a waxwork, which is Drebber's actual camera from ten years ago when he went grave robbing. The lens has dark staining. Evidence 19 is a ten-year-old article about an eyewitness to the Professor's resurrection. The camera is connected to Drebber's grave robbing, which might relate to the Professor's case. 

Wait, Tusspells says she made the mold just before interment (Testimony 2), and she finished before sunrise (Testimony 6). But Evidence 12's camera was used by Drebber ten years ago during grave robbing. If Tusspells was making the mold before the burial, how did Drebber have the camera then? The article (Evidence 19) talks about the resurrection rumor, which might be linked to the waxwork. 

But maybe the contradiction is between Testimony 2 and Evidence 12. Testimony 2 says she created the mold before interment, implying the body was buried. However, the camera (Evidence 12) was used by Drebber during grave robbing. If the mold was made before the body was buried, then Drebber couldn't have robbed the grave before that. But the article (Evidence 19) mentions the resurrection on the night of execution, which would be the same night as the burial. If Tusspells was there making the mold before burial, then Drebber's grave robbing would have to happen after that. But the camera's presence during the grave robbing (which would be after the burial) might conflict with her testimony about creating the mold before interment. Wait, but the camera's dark staining could be blood from the grave robbing, which occurred after the burial. So maybe the timing is conflicting. 

Alternatively, looking at Testimony 3: Tusspells says she hid until he gave a signal and was there a long time. Evidence 12's camera has dark staining on the bellows. If Drebber was grave robbing and took photos, but Tusspells was there making the mold before interment, maybe there's a contradiction in the timeline. Wait, the camera was used ten years ago when Drebber went grave robbing. If Tusspells was making the mold before the burial (Testimony 2), then the body was interred. But the article (Evidence 19) says the resurrection was on the night of execution. So the same night, the body was buried, then someone (Drebber?) tried to dig it up. But Tusspells was there making the mold before interment. If she was there that night until the body was interred at dawn, then Drebber's grave robbing would have to be after that. But the camera was used during the grave robbing. Maybe there's a contradiction in her testimony about the timing and the presence of the camera as evidence of grave robbing. 

Wait, the key contradiction might be between Tusspells' Testimony 2 and Testimony 6. She says she created the mold before interment, and left after the corpse was interred. But Evidence 12 is Drebber's camera from when he went grave robbing ten years ago. If Drebber had the camera during the grave robbing, which would have been after the interment, then the camera's presence isn't directly conflicting. However, Evidence 19's article talks about the resurrection rumor on the night of execution. If the resurrection was due to the waxwork, maybe Tusspells' mold was used to create the Professor's likeness, but Drebber's grave robbing (using the camera) happened the same night. But how does that contradict?

Alternatively, maybe Testimony 3: She hid until he gave a signal and was there a long time. Evidence 12's camera has dark staining (possibly blood) on the bellows. If Drebber used the camera during the grave robbing, which would have been after the burial, but Tusspells was present until the burial, then maybe there's a contradiction. But I'm not sure.

Wait, perhaps the contradiction is between Testimony 2, where Tusspells says she enlisted the gravedigger and made the mold before interment. But the Killer's Autopsy Report (Evidence 16) is of the Professor, who was tried and executed. If the Professor's body was autopsied and buried, but Tusspells made a mold before interment, then the body was intact. However, the Autopsy Report might indicate that the body had certain injuries, which the waxwork would replicate. But maybe the waxwork's head (Evidence 15) was stolen, and the camera (Evidence 12) shows Drebber's involvement. 

Alternatively, looking at Evidence 13: Piece of Broken Glass from the Crystal Tower found on the Professor waxwork. If the waxwork was made from the mold taken before the glass was broken, but the glass came from the explosion during the current case, that could be a contradiction. But the timeline might not match.

Wait, let's think again. The camera (Evidence 12) is from Drebber's grave robbing ten years ago. The article (Evidence 19) is about the Professor's resurrection on the night of his execution. Tusspells' testimonies explain that she made the waxwork head by taking a mold from the corpse before burial. So the waxwork would be an exact likeness. However, if Drebber was grave robbing that same night, perhaps he took the body, which would mean the body wasn't buried, but Tusspells claims she made the mold before interment. But if the body was stolen before burial, how could she make the mold? That's a possible contradiction. 

So, Testimony 2 says she made the mold before interment. But if Drebber stole the body (grave robbing) before it was buried, then the interment never happened. Therefore, Tusspells' testimony about making the mold before interment would conflict with Evidence 12 (the camera used during grave robbing), which suggests the body was stolen before burial. Therefore, her statement that she made the mold before interment (Testimony 2) would be contradicted by the evidence that the body was stolen (via Drebber's camera), meaning the interment didn't happen. But the article (Evidence 19) says there was a resurrection rumor, implying the body was missing. So if the body was stolen before interment, Tusspells couldn't have made the mold after the body was interred. Therefore, the contradiction would be between Testimony 2 and Evidence 19 or 12. 

Alternatively, the direct contradiction is between Testimony 2 (mold made before interment) and Evidence 12 (camera used in grave robbing, which would require the body to have been buried first). But if Drebber robbed the grave after interment, then Tusspells could have made the mold before. However, Evidence 19's article states the resurrection was on the night of execution, which is the same night as the burial. If the grave was robbed that same night, then Tusspells would have made the mold before the interment, and Drebber robbed the grave after. But that's possible. So maybe the contradiction is elsewhere.

Looking at Testimony 3: Tusspells says she hid until he gave a signal and was there a very long time. The "he" might be the gravedigger. Then she made the mold. Evidence 12's camera has dark staining, possibly blood, which could link to the grave robbing. If the grave was robbed the same night, perhaps Tusspells would have noticed. But her testimony doesn't mention that. Alternatively, if the camera was used during the grave robbing, which was after the interment, but Tusspells was there until the interment was done, then maybe the timeline is okay.

Wait, another angle. The waxwork head (Evidence 15) was stolen. The camera (Evidence 12) was part of the exhibit, but it's the actual camera Drebber used. The Autopsy Report (Evidence 16) of the Professor would show the cause of death. If the waxwork's head is accurate because it was made from the mold taken from the corpse, but the autopsy report shows something different, that could be a contradiction. But I don't see direct info here.

Hmm. Let's think again. Which evidence and testimony directly contradict each other? For example, if a testimony says something happened at a certain time, but evidence proves that it couldn't have.

Testimony 2: Tusspells says she created the mold before the interment. But if the body was already stolen (as per the resurrection rumor in Evidence 19), then the interment didn't happen, so she couldn't have made the mold before interment. Therefore, Testimony 2 (mold made before interment) and Evidence 19 (body was resurrected/stolen on the night of execution, implying the body wasn't interred) would contradict. But Evidence 19 is a newspaper article about a rumor. It's possible the rumor was based on the waxwork, not an actual resurrection. Tusspells made the waxwork, which looked like the Professor, leading people to think he was resurrected. So in that case, the body was interred, and the mold was made before that. The article's rumor is because of the waxwork, not a real body theft. So that might not contradict.

Alternatively, Evidence 12: Drebber's camera from when he went grave robbing. If he grave robbed the Professor's body, then the body wasn't in the grave. But Tusspells made the mold before interment, so the body was buried. Therefore, if Drebber stole the body after interment, that's possible. But if the camera was used during the grave robbing, which occurred after interment, then there's no contradiction. So maybe the contradiction is elsewhere.

Wait, let's look at Evidence 16: Killer's Autopsy Report. It's the report of the Professor, who was executed. The autopsy would show cause of death. If Tusspells made the mold from the corpse, the autopsy report's findings (like method of execution) should align with the waxwork. But maybe not directly a contradiction here.

Another angle: Testimony 4 says it took a long time because it was before rigor mortis. Rigor mortis sets in a few hours after death. If the execution was at a certain time, and Tusspells took the mold before rigor mortis, that would mean she did it soon after death. But the article (Evidence 19) says the resurrection was on the night of execution, which would be the same time. If the body was moved after Tusspells made the mold, but before burial, perhaps. But how does that contradict?

Alternatively, Testimony 6 says she finished in the half hour before sunrise and left after the corpse was interred. Evidence 19's article says the resurrection was witnessed that same night. If the interment happened at sunrise, then the resurrection rumor (which is the same night) would be before the interment. Therefore, the article's event (resurrection) happened before the body was buried, which contradicts Tusspells' statement that she left after interment. So if the resurrection was witnessed before interment, but she says she left after interment, that's a contradiction. But the article is a rumor, so maybe it's not reliable.

Alternatively, the camera (Evidence 12) has dark staining, which could be blood from the grave robbing. If Drebber used it to take pictures during the grave robbing, which would be after interment, but Tusspells was present until interment. So there's no direct contradiction here.

Wait, another angle. The waxwork's head (Evidence 15) was stolen. The camera (Evidence 12) was part of the exhibit. The broken glass (Evidence 13) from the Crystal Tower was found on the waxwork. The explosion at the Great Exhibition caused the glass to break. So if the waxwork was present during the explosion, the glass could have gotten on it. But the Professor's waxwork was made ten years ago. How did the glass from the recent explosion get on it? That's a contradiction. But Evidence 13 is a piece of glass from the Crystal Tower found on the Professor waxwork. The explosion happened during the current case, so the glass from the Tower would have been broken then. But the waxwork was in the exhibit, so how did the glass get there unless the waxwork was at the explosion site. That suggests the waxwork was moved there, which could be part of the crime. But how does that contradict a testimony?

Alternatively, the contradiction is between Testimony 2 (mold made before interment) and Evidence 12 (camera used in grave robbing). If Drebber grave robbed the body, then the body wasn't interred, so Tusspells couldn't have made the mold before interment. Therefore, Testimony 2 and Evidence 12 contradict. But how?

Wait, the camera is evidence that Drebber went grave robbing ten years ago. If he did that, then he might have stolen the body. But if the body was stolen, then Tusspells couldn't have made the mold before interment because the body wasn't buried. Therefore, her Testimony 2 would be a lie. Therefore, Evidence 12 (camera from grave robbing) contradicts Testimony 2 (mold made before interment). That seems like a possible contradiction.

So the pair would be Evidence 12 and Testimony 2. But I need to check the exact details. Testimony 2: "I enlisted the aid of the gravedigger, and created a mould for the head in the cemetery just before the interment." So she made the mold just before the body was buried. If Drebber then stole the body after interment, that's possible. But if the body was stolen before interment (as per the article's rumor), then the interment didn't happen, so she couldn't have made the mold before. But the article (Evidence 19) is about a resurrection rumor on the night of execution. If the rumor was due to the waxwork, then the body was interred, and the mold was made as she said. But the camera evidence shows Drebber was grave robbing, which would be after interment, so no contradiction. Therefore, maybe the contradiction is elsewhere.

Alternatively, Testimony 3: "I hid myself until he gave me a signal. ...I was there for a very long time that night." The "he" could be the gravedigger. Evidence 12's camera has dark staining, perhaps from blood during grave robbing. If the grave robbing happened that same night, and Tusspells was present until interment, then Drebber couldn't have robbed the grave until after she left. But the camera's presence implies he was there. However, without timing specifics, it's hard to say.

Alternatively, Testimony 6: She left after the corpse was interred. Evidence 19's article says the resurrection was witnessed on the night of execution, which would be the same night. If the interment happened at dawn (as per Testimony 5 and 6), then the resurrection rumor (same night) would be before the interment, which contradicts because the body wasn't buried yet. But the article is a rumor, so maybe it's based on the waxwork being seen, not the actual body.

Hmm, this is tricky. Maybe another approach: look for direct contradictions in statements. For example, a testimony that says one thing, but evidence that proves the opposite.

Testimony 2 says Tusspells made the mold before interment. If Evidence 12 (the camera) shows that the body was exhumed (grave robbing), implying the body was buried. So if the body was buried, then interment happened. So no contradiction. But if the body was never buried because Drebber stole it before interment, then Testimony 2 is false. But how does Evidence 12 show that?

Wait, the camera is from Drebber's grave robbing. The article (Evidence 19) talks about the resurrection rumor. If the resurrection was due to the body being stolen, then the mold couldn't have been made before interment because the body wasn't interred. Therefore, Tusspells' Testimony 2 would be contradicted by Evidence 19. But Evidence 19 is an article about a rumor, which might not be factual. The actual truth might be that the waxwork caused the rumor, and the body was interred normally. So Tusspells' testimony is true, and the article's rumor is because of the waxwork. Hence, no contradiction.

Wait, but the camera (Evidence 12) is the actual camera used by Drebber during grave robbing. If he used it to take photos of the exhumed body, that would mean the body was indeed stolen. So if the body was stolen, then Tusspells couldn't have made the mold before interment because the body was never buried. Therefore, Testimony 2 is contradicted by Evidence 12. Because if Drebber robbed the grave, the body wasn't interred, so Tusspells couldn't have made the mold before interment. Therefore, the contradiction is between Testimony 2 (mold made before interment) and Evidence 12 (camera proving grave robbery, meaning no interment).

Yes, that makes sense. If the body was stolen by Drebber, then it was never interred. Therefore, Tusspells' claim that she made the mold before interment would be impossible, as the body wasn't buried. Hence, the camera evidence (12) contradicts Testimony 2.

prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Susato Mikotoba
Description: A judicial assistant sent to Britain on a study tour. She's the epitome of a refined Japanese lady and a huge help to me always.
Character 1
Name: Iris Wilson
Description: An extraordinary young girl who lives with Mr Sholmes. She has a degree in medicine and is the author of a popular series of short stories.
Character 2
Name: Herlock Sholmes
Description: There's not a person in the world who hasn't heard of this famous great detective, whose deductions never fail to surprise.
Character 3
Name: Mael Stronghart
Description: The Lord Chief Justice, who wields absolute authority in judicial matters, including the appointment of lawyers. He's a thoroughly intimidating man.
Character 4
Name: Odie Asman
Description: The man who perished in the explosion on the experimentation stage at the Great Exhibition of London.↳The man who perished in the explosion on the experimentation stage. He was Professor Harebrayne's financial backer and the boss of a large criminal organisation.
Character 5
Name: Albert Harebrayne
Description: A scientist who invented a machine to demonstrate super-high-voltage instantaneous kinesis. However, it exploded in use, and he is now accused of murder.↳A scientist who invented a machine to demonstrate super-high-voltage instantaneous kinesis. He's the defendant of this case and a friend to Lord van Zieks, apparently.
Character 6
Name: Barok van Zieks
Description: A prosecutor known as the Reaper of the Bailey. Supposedly, the souls of those he prosecutes are eternally damned, one way or another.
Character 7
Name: Masked Man
Description: An apprentice of Lord van Zieks whose face is always covered by a mask. He has the air of a completely unassailable man.
Character 8
Name: Gina Lestrade
Description: A mostly reformed pickpocket who's now a self-appointed 'detective inspector'. She's really making waves in her new apprenticeship.
Character 9
Name: Tobias Gregson
Description: The detective inspector in charge of Scotland Yard's investigation of the case. He's stern and single-minded in his approach, and a great lover of fish and chips.
Character 10
Name: Esmeralda Tusspells
Description: The proprietress of the Madame Tusspells Museum of Waxwork and the latest in a line of artisans privy to the secret Tusspells technique of capturing a perfect likeness.
Character 11
Name: Balthazar Lune
Description: The impresario of short pleasure voyages in flying balloons. The balloons above the experimentation state all belonged to this man.
Character 12
Name: Bohemian Boy
Description: A young boy who came to London to visit the Great Exhibition. His real name is Wilhelm Gottsreich Sigismond Ormstein.↳A young prince from the royal family of Bohemia with an excessively long name. He witnessed the explosion at the Great Exhibition.
Character 13
Name: Courtney Sithe
Description: Scotland Yard coroner, leader of the Forensic Investigation Team and one of Lord Stronghart's most trusted allies.
Character 14
Name: Enoch Drebber
Description: A trickster who seems to be both an engineer and a magician. He constructed the machine for Professor Harebrayne's demonstration.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Armband
Description: An armband I inherited from Kazuma. It identifies the wearer as a defence lawyer throughout the Empire of Japan.
Evidence 1
Name: Great Exhibition Newspaper
Description: A newspaper containing various articles about the world-leading science and technology on show at the Great Exhibition being held in London.
Evidence 2
Name: Experiment Sketch
Description: A diagram showing the relative positions of the Crystal Tower and Professor Harebrayne's machine that exploded.
Evidence 3
Name: Mysterious Contraption → Crossbow
Description: A very curious device found behind a tree under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds, almost as if it had been hidden there deliberately. A weapon found hidden behind a tree under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds. It turns out that it's a folding crossbow. A crossbow found hidden behind a tree under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds. It belongs to Mr Enoch Drebber.
Evidence 4
Name: Piece of Green Cloth
Description: A torn piece of canvas-like material backed with rubber that was found under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds. There are scorch marks at the edges.
Evidence 5
Name: Photograph of the Victim
Description: A photographic print of the victim taken after he had ostensibly been 'beamed' to the Crystal Tower. It shows an apparent stab wound to the chest.
Evidence 6
Name: Autopsy Report
Description: The autopsy report of the victim, Mr Asman. His neck was broken from the impact of a violent fall and he was stabbed in the chest with a sharp object.
Evidence 7
Name: Screwdriver
Description: Professor Harebrayne's trusty screwdriver that he's named 'Andrew'. There are traces of blood at the tip and it matches the shape of the victim's wound. A metal screwdriver that was found poking through the grille in the base of what remains of the kinesis machine. It has a very distinctive handle.
Evidence 8
Name: Photograph of the Balloon
Description: A photograph taken by Gotts whilst he was riding in a balloon. It shows another balloon that he claims was green and exploded moments after he took this shot.
Evidence 9
Name: Drebber's Card
Description: Mr Enoch Drebber's business card, though it shows only the man's name. There is no address. Mr Enoch Drebber's business card, which lists no address for the man. There is a smear of machine oil on the reverse.
Evidence 10
Name: Wooden 'Birdcage'
Description: The wooden cage that was used for Professor Harebrayne's experiment. This cage, with the victim inside, crashed down into the Crystal Tower. The wooden cage that was used for the demonstration. It crashed down, with the victim inside, into the Crystal Tower causing damage to its base.
Evidence 11
Name: Photograph of Drebber
Description: A photographic print of the engineer, Mr Enoch Drebber. It's hard to make out, but he appears to be wearing a monocle with black glass.
Evidence 12
Name: Camera
Description: The camera from around the neck of a waxwork in the Madame Tusspells Special Exhibit. The actual camera that Mr Drebber had with him ten years ago when he went graverobbing. The actual camera that Mr Drebber had with him ten years ago when he went graverobbing. When the lens is extended, dark staining can be seen on the bellows.
Evidence 13
Name: Piece of Broken Glass
Description: A small fragment of very unusual and thick glass that was found in the folds of the clothing of the Professor waxwork. It would appear to be from the Crystal Tower.
Evidence 14
Name: Science Trophy
Description: A Royal Society trophy for excellence in science that was found in Mr Drebber's workshop. It's a very prestigious award for a young scientist.
Evidence 15
Name: Waxwork Head
Description: The head of the Professor waxwork that was stolen from the Madame Tusspells Special Exhibit.
Evidence 16
Name: Killer's Autopsy Report
Description: The autopsy report of the mass murderer known as the Professor, who was tried and found guilty by closed trial ten years ago.
Evidence 17
Name: Post-Explosion Photograph
Description: A photographic print of the experimentation stage after it was completely levelled by a time bomb. The metal floor of the stage has been blown open by the explosion.
Evidence 18
Name: Drebber's Contract
Description: The contract between Mr Asman and Mr Drebber detailing the terms by which they would profit from the kinesis experiment.
Evidence 19
Name: Ten-Year-Old Article
Description: A newspaper article recounting the tale of an eyewitness to the alleged 'resurrection' of the Professor from his grave on the night of his execution.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: The reason I was in Lowgate Cemetery at all ten years ago was for...a spot of moonlighting, shall we say?
Person: Drebber
Testimony 1
Testimony: Yes, the illustration in that newspaper article was based on what I witnessed that night.
Person: Drebber
Testimony 2
Testimony: Thinking back now, I realise that I never actually saw the Professor at all, though.
Person: Drebber
Testimony 3
Testimony: What I in fact witnessed, was a fellow graverobber at work.
Person: Drebber
Testimony 4
Testimony: There was no gunshot from behind me at all. Nor any splattering blood.
Person: Drebber
Testimony 5
Testimony: Soon afterwards, I was visited by a young woman who sculpted a model of me from wax.
Person: Drebber
Testimony 6
Testimony: Then I gave up on my dream of becoming a scientist. And it was all because of that newspaper article.
Person: Drebber

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, let's see. I need to find which evidence and testimony contradict each other. The user provided a list of characters, evidences, and testimonies, and I have to pick one pair where the evidence contradicts a testimony.

First, I'll go through the testimonies. All the testimonies are from Drebber (Testimony 0 to 6). Let me read them one by one.

Testimony 0: Drebber was in Lowgate Cemetery ten years ago for "moonlighting" (probably graverobbing, as per later testimonies). Testimony 1 says the newspaper article's illustration is based on what he witnessed. Testimony 2 says he didn't actually see the Professor. Testimony 3 states he saw a fellow graverobber. Testimony 4 mentions no gunshot or blood. Testimony 5 says a young woman made a wax model of him. Testimony 6 says he gave up being a scientist because of the article.

Now looking at the evidences. Let's check which ones relate to Drebber or the events ten years ago. 

Evidence 12 is the camera from Madame Tusspells' exhibit, which was Drebber's actual camera from ten years ago when he went graverobbing. The description mentions dark staining on the bellows when the lens is extended. 

Testimony 3: Drebber says he witnessed a fellow graverobber. But if the camera (Evidence 12) has dark staining, maybe blood? If the newspaper article (Evidence 19) talks about the Professor's resurrection, and Drebber's testimony says he saw another graverobber, but the camera from that time (Evidence 12) might have blood, which contradicts his statement that there was no blood (Testimony 4). Wait, Testimony 4 says there was no gunshot or blood. But the camera (Evidence 12) has dark staining, possibly blood, which would contradict his testimony. 

Wait, let me check. Evidence 12's description: "dark staining can be seen on the bellows." If that staining is blood, then Drebber's Testimony 4 ("no splattering blood") would be contradicted. But how do we know the staining is blood? The autopsy report (Evidence 16) is about the Professor. Alternatively, the stain could be from machine oil, but Drebber's Card (Evidence 9) has machine oil on the reverse. Hmm.

Alternatively, Testimony 5 says a young woman (probably Esmeralda Tusspells) sculpted a wax model of him. Evidence 15 is the stolen waxwork head of the Professor. But the camera (Evidence 12) was used by Drebber during the graverobbing. If the camera was his, and the staining is from blood, then Testimony 4's claim of no blood would be contradicted by the blood on the camera. But the staining is described as "dark staining"—could that be blood? The Autopsy Report (Evidence 6) mentions a stab wound. But maybe the camera's staining is blood from the Professor's corpse when Drebber was graverobbing. If Drebber said there was no blood (Testimony 4), but the camera has blood stains, that's a contradiction.

So the pair would be Evidence 12 (Camera) and Testimony 4 (no blood). But Evidence 12's description doesn't explicitly say it's blood, just dark staining. However, considering the context, the staining might be blood. Alternatively, Testimony 1 where Drebber says the newspaper article's illustration was based on his witness, but Evidence 19 is the ten-year-old article about the Professor's resurrection. If the article's illustration was based on Drebber's account, but Evidence 12 (the camera) would have a photograph that contradicts his account. Wait, Evidence 12 is the camera Drebber had when graverobbing. But the article (Evidence 19) is based on his testimony. However, Testimony 2 says Drebber never actually saw the Professor. If the article's illustration (from Evidence 19) is based on his account, but he didn't see the Professor, then the illustration would be inaccurate, but how does that relate to evidence?

Alternatively, Testimony 6: Drebber gave up science because of the article. But Evidence 14 is a Science Trophy from Drebber's workshop. If he gave up science, why does he have a trophy? But maybe the trophy is from before he gave up. The trophy's description says it's a prestigious award for a young scientist. If he gave up, but has a trophy, that's not necessarily a contradiction. Maybe he earned it before quitting.

Another angle: Testimony 3 says Drebber saw a fellow graverobber, but Evidence 12's camera was his own. If the camera was used to take pictures, maybe there's a photo that shows something conflicting. But the camera's evidence description says it's the actual camera he had when graverobbing. The dark staining could be from blood, which would contradict Testimony 4 where he says there was no blood. But unless the evidence directly shows blood, this is speculative.

Alternatively, Testimony 1: Drebber says the newspaper article's illustration was based on his witness. Evidence 19 is the ten-year-old article. The article's illustration would show the Professor, but Drebber's Testimony 2 says he never saw the Professor, only a graverobber. Therefore, the article's illustration is based on his account but depicts the Professor, which he didn't see. So the article's illustration (Evidence 19) contradicts Testimony 2. But Evidence 19 is the article, and Testimony 2 says he didn't see the Professor. So if the article's illustration is of the Professor, then the testimony that he didn't see the Professor contradicts the article's claim that the illustration is based on his account. Therefore, Evidence 19 (Ten-Year-Old Article) and Testimony 1 (he confirmed the illustration was based on his witness) would contradict each other because if he didn't see the Professor (Testimony 2), then the illustration shouldn't be of the Professor. But Testimony 1 says "Yes, the illustration in that newspaper article was based on what I witnessed that night." But if he witnessed a graverobber (Testimony 3) and not the Professor, then the illustration in the article (which is about the Professor's resurrection) must have depicted the Professor, which contradicts his actual testimony. Therefore, the contradiction is between Testimony 1 (he confirmed the illustration was based on his account) and the fact that the article's illustration shows the Professor, which he didn't see. But the evidence here would be Evidence 19 (the article), and the testimony is Testimony 1. But how does Evidence 19's content show that? The article's description says it recounts an eyewitness to the Professor's resurrection. If Drebber's testimony says he didn't see the Professor but the article uses his account to depict the resurrection, that's a contradiction. Therefore, the evidence is Evidence 19, and the testimony is Testimony 1. Alternatively, Testimony 2 where he says he never saw the Professor, which contradicts the article (Evidence 19) which is about the Professor's resurrection based on his account. Wait, but Testimony 1 is him agreeing that the illustration is based on his witness. So if the illustration is of the Professor's resurrection, but he actually saw a graverobber, then Testimony 1 is a lie, and the evidence (article's illustration) contradicts his actual testimony (Testimony 2 and 3). So the contradiction would be between Evidence 19 (the article about the resurrection) and Testimony 3 (he saw a graverobber, not the Professor). But the user wants one pair: evidence and testimony. So the article (Evidence 19) contradicts Testimony 1, where Drebber says the illustration is based on his account, but the article's content is about the Professor's resurrection, which he didn't witness. Therefore, Evidence 19 and Testimony 1. But the user might consider the contradiction between the article's claim (based on Drebber's account) and Drebber's Testimony 2 (he never saw the Professor). Alternatively, maybe Evidence 12 (the camera) and Testimony 3 (he saw a fellow graverobber). Wait, the camera is Drebber's own, so if he was there for graverobbing (Testimony 0), and the camera was used to take photos, but the camera has dark staining (maybe blood from the Professor's corpse?), which would imply that there was blood, contradicting Testimony 4 where he says there was no blood. So Evidence 12 (Camera with staining) contradicts Testimony 4 (no blood). But how do we know the staining is blood? The description says "dark staining can be seen on the bellows." If that's blood, then it's a contradiction. But another evidence, Evidence 9 (Drebber's Card) has machine oil. Maybe the staining is oil. But the camera's staining is on the bellows, which could be from blood. Alternatively, in the context of the game, the staining might be blood, which would mean that there was blood, contradicting Drebber's Testimony 4. Therefore, the pair would be Evidence 12 and Testimony 4. But I need to be sure. Let me check the evidence and testimonies again.

Testimony 4: "There was no gunshot from behind me at all. Nor any splattering blood." So Drebber claims there was no blood. But Evidence 12's camera has dark staining, which could be blood. If the staining is blood, then that contradicts his testimony. The question is whether the dark staining is blood. Since the camera was used during the graverobbing incident, and the article (Evidence 19) talks about the Professor's resurrection, maybe the blood is from the Professor's body, implying that Drebber's account of no blood is false. Therefore, the contradiction is Evidence 12 (camera with blood stains) and Testimony 4 (no blood). However, the description of Evidence 12 doesn't explicitly state it's blood, but the game might imply that. Another angle: The autopsy report (Evidence 16) of the Professor mentions cause of death. If the Professor was executed, perhaps the body had wounds. If Drebber was graverobbing and took photos, the camera's stains could be blood from the corpse. But Drebber's Testimony 4 says no blood, but the camera has stains. Therefore, Evidence 12 contradicts Testimony 4. That seems plausible. So the answer would be {"evidence": 12, "testimony": 4}.

cot:
Okay, let me try to figure this out. So the task is to find which evidence and testimony contradict each other. The user wants one pair. Let's start by going through the testimonies and the evidences to see where there's a conflict.

First, looking at the testimonies from Courtney Sithe. Testimony 3 says the actual cause of death was neck trauma from a 30-foot fall.
